Took a question about dark money in our elections. Let’s be clear here, corporations aren’t people and Montanans know that. If you put a bill on the floor of the Senate that clarified that, it would pass.

Was just asked about civic engagement. The decisions we make today will have a tremendous impact on young people in this country. As leaders we can inspire the next generation by keeping politics out of our decision making and doing what’s right for the country. It’s that simple.

I just got a question about suicide rates in Montana. I've got a bill to address this crisis that would be a good start, but we have to keep pushing. We need more mental health professionals on the ground and we have to reduce the stigma around mental health in rural America.

Was just asked about our climate. We’ve got ice sheets that are melting, we’ve got oceans that are rising, we’ve got bugs in our crops and in our forests that we've never had before. We have to work together to do something about our changing climate.

Just got a question about legislative gridlock in the Senate. We're supposed to be the greatest deliberative body in the world, but we don't debate much anymore. If we actually did the work of debating the issues, I think we'd come up with a whole heckuva lot more solutions.

One of the first questions is about protecting public lands. Let's be clear, one of the things that makes Montana great is our public lands. You don't have to be a millionaire and own a ranch to go hunting or a stream to go fishing. I'm always going to fight to keep it that way.

Folks in Montana have shown Washington the way — now it’s time for Congress to follow Montana’s lead.
There’s no reason why we cannot make smart investments in working families, our children’s education, and 21st century infrastructure without bankrupting the future for our kids and grandkids.
It is possible to be fiscally responsible without cutting working folks off at the knees — I negotiated and passed a balanced budget while serving as the President of the Montana Senate.

Spending is about priorities. 

It’s clear that Congress’ priorities are out of whack.

These same colleagues that added this 2 trillion dollars of debt are now arguing we don’t have enough money to provide for our veterans, pay for Medicare, Social Security, and other programs that protect hundreds of thousands of Montanans.

They promised this tax giveaway would pay for itself — it did not. 

In fact, it tacked 2 trillion dollars into the national debt.
My Republican colleagues passed a partisan tax giveaway that was drafted behind closed doors with no public input form Montanans.
Our debt is not skyrocketing because we are spending it on things we need like updates infrastructure or investments in education — it’s skyrocketing because of irresponsible spending.
The bipartisan Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget projects that this Administration’s policies will add 4 trillion dollars to the debt over the next ten years.

This week, we will vote on a bill that swipes Washington’s credit card to the tune of about 250 billion dollars over the next two years — dollars are coming from the pockets of our kids and grandkids.
As usual, Washington could learn a lot from Montana.
Folks in Montana are resilient and resourceful — they know how to live within their means.
As I travel across Montana, I hear from folks who work tirelessly everyday to make ends meet — families facing the ever-rising costs of housing, healthcare, and other basic necessities.

I’m headed to the Senate floor in a few moments to discuss how Montana common sense can help solve our skyrocketing national debt.
